titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Gifford Pinchot (1865-1946) was the first Chief of the United States Forest Service (1905-1910) and twice the Governor of Pennsylvania (1923-1927, 1931-1935). He is famous for reforming the management and development of forests in the United States and for advocating conservation of the nation's forest reserves by planned use and renewal. He coined the term conservation as applied to natural resources.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of glass and film negatives documenting Pinchot's expeditions to the Galapagos and the Caribbean. Photos show Pinchot, Cornelia Bryce Pinchot, Dr. Henry A. Pilsbry, and other expedition members. Photo sleeves are labeled, and there is also a typed description of some of the images. The collection also includes letters (typescript) written by his wife, Cornelia Bryce Pinchot, describing a trip to Iran in 1949, including interactions with other Western visitors, and an audience with the Shah.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
